general_requirements.statewide_program_name: Florida streamlined permitting for Tier 1 solar systems (up to 10 kW on single-family residential). No insurance requirement and no application fee for Tier 1 grid connection.

interconnection.net_metering_details: Florida has net metering for systems up to 115% of customer's prior 12-month energy consumption. Credits at full retail rate. Excess credits roll over indefinitely at retail rate. No cap on statewide capacity. FPL, Duke Energy Florida, and TECO are major utilities.
interconnection.fees: No application fee for Tier 1 systems; varies for larger systems

special_considerations.hoa_restrictions: Strong solar access law (Florida Statute 163.04). Property owners cannot be denied permission to install solar collectors by any deed restriction, covenant, or HOA. One of the strongest solar rights laws in the nation.
special_considerations.historic_districts: Historic districts in St. Augustine, Key West, and other cities have additional review requirements. Local historic preservation boards review installations.
special_considerations.wind_load_requirements: Critical requirement. Florida Building Code has the most stringent wind ratings in the nation. Miami-Dade County: 175 mph design wind speed. Broward County: 170 mph. Most of peninsular Florida: 130-160 mph. All installations must meet FBC wind load requirements. Hurricane zone compliance is mandatory.

licensing.license_type: Florida Solar Contractor license (CVC56875) or licensed Electrical Contractor (EC). Florida-specific solar contractor license is unique in the nation.

notes: Florida is the second-largest solar market in the US after California. The state has strong net metering and solar access laws but no state income tax credit (residential ITC expired federally Jan 2026). Property tax exemption for solar equipment value. Sales tax exemption on solar equipment. Hurricane wind load compliance is the most critical permitting consideration - installations must withstand extreme wind speeds. FPL is the largest utility and has streamlined interconnection. The state blocked anti-solar ballot measure in 2016.

jurisdictions.name: Jacksonville
jurisdictions.fire_code_requirements: Florida Building Code fire setbacks. Standard access pathways.
jurisdictions.notes: HB 683 mandates 5 business day review with auto-approval if missed. Permit fees $125-$275 range. Wind load calcs required.

jurisdictions.name: Miami
jurisdictions.fire_code_requirements: High-Velocity Hurricane Zone (HVHZ) requirements. Enhanced wind load standards for all solar installations.
special_requirements: HVHZ enhanced wind load standards mandatory
Miami-Dade product approvals may be required
jurisdictions.notes: Strictest solar permitting in Florida due to HVHZ designation. All installations must meet enhanced wind load standards. PE stamp required for virtually all systems.

jurisdictions.name: Tampa
jurisdictions.fire_code_requirements: Florida Building Code fire setbacks. Wind load requirements for coastal location.
jurisdictions.notes: HB 683 5-day review mandate with auto-approval. Residential permits $200-$500 based on system size. Private inspection providers now allowed.

jurisdictions.name: Orlando
jurisdictions.notes: Orange County expedited solar permit program. Fees $100-$300. Most residential reviewed within 3-5 business days.

jurisdictions.name: St. Petersburg
jurisdictions.fire_code_requirements: Florida Building Code setbacks. Coastal wind load requirements.
jurisdictions.notes: HB 683 5-day review mandate. Duke Energy Florida serves most of the area.

jurisdictions.name: Hialeah
jurisdictions.fire_code_requirements: HVHZ requirements same as Miami-Dade County.
jurisdictions.notes: In Miami-Dade County HVHZ zone. Same strict wind load requirements as Miami.

jurisdictions.name: Port St. Lucie
jurisdictions.fire_code_requirements: Florida Building Code setbacks. Wind load requirements.
jurisdictions.notes: Standard Florida permitting with HB 683 5-day mandate.
